thread.title: Election fever hits Westminster as MPs compete for Committee chair roles

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Election fever hits Westminster as MPs compete for Committee chair roles
text:
Election fever hits Westminster as MPs compete for Committee chair roles MPs from across the region are standing for election - and the voters are their fellow politicians Share Labour Party's Bridget Phillipson (Image: PA) Share Get daily updates   
Election fever has hit Westminster again, as candidates compete for key roles chairing influential Commons committees . 
Bridget Phillipson , Labour MP for Houghton and Sunderland South, hopes to become chair of the Commons Transport Committee. 
It holds inquiries into the Government’s transport policies, summoning Ministers and industry leaders such as top managers at rail or bus companies to be interrogated. 
But she’s up against four rival candidates, in a contest which will be decided by a ballot of MPs. 
In an appeal for their support, she said: “Since I entered Parliament in 2010, I’ve campaigned tirelessly for a better local bus service for the North East of England.” 
She added: “At present, UK rail and bus passengers face overcrowding, delays and ever-rising ticket prices. I will make the case for an efficient and affordable rail and bus network that promotes economic growth, protects the interests of the travelling public and delivers value for the taxpayer.” 
Only Labour MPs are able to stand for the post, because committee chair positions are divided up between the parties before candidates come forward. 
However, MPs from all parties are able to vote, which means Ms Phillipson, along with the other candidates, needs to try to win support from Tory as well as Labour MPs and those from other parties. Gateshead MP Ian Mearns 
Gateshead MP Ian Mearns is standing again to be chair of the Backbench Business Committee, which helps decide what gets debated in the House of Commons. Read More 
He has chaired the Committee since June 2015, but now faces a challenge from Angela Smith, a Labour MP representing a Yorkshire constituency. 
Voting takes place on Wednesday 12 July, and candidates will be busy canvassing colleagues until then. 
North East MPs have already snapped up a number of key roles in the front benches of the two major parties. 
Hexham Conservative MP Guy Opperman is a Pensions Minister. 
And Jeremy Corbyn has appointed a number of the region’s Labour MPs to his top team. 
Bishop Auckland MP Helen Goodman has been made a junior shadow minister in Labour’s foreign affairs team. 
City of Durham MP Roberta Blackman-Woods is a shadow international development minister. Lord Beecham (Image: newcastle chronicle) 
Lord Beecham, a former leader of Newcastle City Council, continues as a Communities and Local Government spokesman in the House of Lords and Darlington MP Jenny Chapman is a shadow Brexit minister. 
South Shields MP Emma Lewell-Buck is a shadow children and families minister, while Newcastle Central MP Chi Onwurah continues as shadow minister for the industrial strategy. 
North Tyneside MP Mary Glindon is a shadow farming minister and Stockton South MP Alex Cunningham MP is a shadow pensions minister. 
They join North East MPs in high profile and senior roles include Middlesbrough MP Andy McDonald, the Shadow Secretary of State for Transport, Newcastle upon Tyne East MP Nick Brown, the Opposition Chief Whip, and Wansbeck MP Ian Lavery, the Labour chair and joint election co-ordinator.
